Title: Apace Communications, Ltd. v. Burke

Headnote: Under New York law, when the corporation is essentially an alter ego of a family or individual, the corporate veil may be pierced and that family or individual held personally liable for what were ostensibly the acts of the corporation.

Title: Apace Communications, Ltd. v. Burke
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory must generally show that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: In re Storer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Under Montana law, courts require presence of two general factors before they will disregard the separate and distinct identity of corporation: (1) that corporation is a mere agent or alter ego; and (2) that corporate cloak was used to defeat the public convenience, to justify wrong, to perpetrate fraud, or to defend crime.

Title: Taurus IP v. DaimlerChrysler Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: In Wisconsin, the use of a corporation to perpetrate a fraud is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil; for purposes of the "alter ego" doctrine, there must also be proof that, for the transaction being attacked, an entity's finances, policy and business practice are dominated so completely that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own.

Title: Hoffmann v. Dandurand
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Examples of where corporate form has been used to achieve unequitable result, as will support application of alter ego theory to disregard corporate fiction that corporation is separate legal entity that insulates its owners or shareholders from personal liability, include: (1) where corporate fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud; (2) where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; (3) where corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation; (4) where corporate fiction is used to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; (5) where corporate fiction is used to circumvent statute; or (6) where corporate fiction is relied on as protection of crime or to justify wrongdoing. Title: Meshel v. Ohev Sholom Talmud Torah
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Although no single factor is dispositive in determining whether the two necessary elements for piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory have been proved, which elements are the existence of a unity of ownership and interest and the use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong, courts are required to consider a range of factors, including whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether there has been any commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, staff, and property, whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, whether the corporation is adequately capitalized, and, especially, whether the corporate form has been used to effectuate a fraud.

The District Court, Highsmith, J., held that: (1) federal law, rather than state law, applied to issue of piercing the corporate veil, and (2) piercing of the corporate veil of customer was appropriate and, thus, corporation was liable, as alter ego of customer, for final judgment for unpaid charges and for attorney fees and costs. Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Shreveport Division. .

Reversed.

On plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Spiegel, J., held that: (1) Ohio choice of law rules applied; (2) under New York law, parent corporation's ownership of all of subsidiary's stock did not justify piercing corporate veil, and fact that parent's checks had been used to make recent payments to plaintiff did not unequivocally establish that parent had assumed subsidiary's obligations; and (3) genuine issues of material fact, as to whether parent and subsidiary had operated in such a manner as to justify piercing corporate veil, precluded summary judgment. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Geyer v. Ingersoll Publications Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Alter ego claim is distinct from contract claim and is equitable in nature.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor filed suit against corporation and corporate director for their alleged fiduciary breaches and fraudulent conveyances.  On defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction and failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted, the Chancery Court, Chandler, Vice Chancellor, held that: (1) corporation is insolvent, such that corporate director will owe fiduciary duties to corporation's creditors, whenever it is insolvent in fact, though no statutory proceedings have been filed against it; (2) Delaware court's exercise of personal jurisdiction over nonresident director of Delaware corporation did not violate due process; and (3) allegations in creditor's complaint were sufficient to state claim against corporation under Fraudulent Conveyances Act. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Link v. Leadworks Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded under alter ego doctrine when domination and control over corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; that domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act; and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: SUCCESSOR LIABILITY - Continuation of Transferor. Whether transferee corporation was continuation of transferor was fact question.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: United Elec., Radio and Mach. Workers of America v. 163 Pleasant Street Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In deciding which veil piercing test to apply in federal court, court looks closely at purpose of federal statute to determine whether statute places importance on corporate forum; less respect to corporate form is generally given than to strict common-law alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Union sued employer and employer's foreign parent alleging that employer's planned cessation of health care payments after its closing would violate Massachusetts common law, Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA), and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA). The Court of Appeals, Selya, Circuit Judge, held that there was insufficient evidence to find that Scottish parent corporation purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities in Massachusetts, and, thus, court lacked jurisdiction over Scottish parent of Delaware employer. Reversed and remanded.

Title: In re Rave Communications, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced when corporation is "dummy" for its stockholders, who are in reality carrying on business in their own personal capacities for purely personal, rather than corporate, ends.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 trustee filed amended complaint against firms closely related to debtor, and officers and board members of the firms, to pierce the corporate veil and hold firms and officers and board members liable for all of debtor's debts, and to avoid allegedly fraudulent transfers. All defendants moved for dismissal for failure to plead charges of fraud with particularity. The Bankruptcy Court, Cornelius Blackshear, J., held that: (1) complaint satisfied particularity requirements for fraud claims, and (2) complaint sufficiently stated claim to litigate propriety of piercing corporate veil. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: United Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Progress Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under "identity" rule, corporate veil may be pierced when plaintiff shows such a unity of interest in ownership that independence of corporation had in effect ceased or never begun, and adherence to fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting economic entity to escape liability arising out of operation conducted by one corporation for benefit of whole enterprise.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought suit to recover money owing for electrical work performed on construction project, as well as to set aside alleged fraudulent conveyance to wife of president of corporation that owned land.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Waterbury, Pellegrino, J., entered judgment in favor of subcontractor on suit against corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor on project, but refused to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on either president or his wife.  Subcontractor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Norcott, J., held that: (1) president's wife was bound, no less than other defendants, by admission in answer, and (2) corporate veil should have been pierced to hold president personally liable on debt. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Canario v. Lidelco, Inc.

Title: Bergman v. Nicholson Management and Consultants, Inc.

Headnote: Corporation will be disregarded and shareholder held liable where corporation is simply alter ego of shareholder; however, before corporate entity will be disregarded on that basis, proof of fraud or deceit, practiced by shareholder when acting for corporation, is usually required. DiRosa, J., denied claim for waste of property against sole shareholder and denied claim against sole shareholder on continuing guaranty.  Vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Williams, J., held that: (1) when sole shareholder as guarantor paid total sum due after primary obligor's notice to vendors that it was unable to timely pay balance due under note but before vendors made forced collection on it, payment satisfied shareholder's obligation to vendors, and (2) sole owner could not be held liable for corporate waste of property. Affirmed. Schott, C.J., and Armstrong, J., concurred in the result.

Title: Riggins v. Dixie Shoring Co., Inc.

Title: Terren v. Butler
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" allows plaintiffs to pierce corporate veil and place liability of corporation at feet of one or more of its principals.
Document Preview: Condominium association and puchasers of individual unit brought action against condominium declarant and its shareholders for breach of warranty and misrepresentations.  The Superior Court, Belknap County, Dickson, J., entered judgment against the declarant and its sole shareholders.  Appeals were taken. The Supreme Court, Horton, J., held that: (1) the one-year life of warranties given by developers is not a statute of limitations, but rather, requires that the defect giving rise to the breach of warranty claim manifest itself within one year; (2) the evidence supported the trial court's decision to pierce the corporate veil and hold the shareholders liable for misrepresentations; and (3) the statute permitting an award of attorney fees to a purchaser in a rescission action did not apply. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Marett v. Professional Ins. Careers, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To establish basis for disregarding corporate entity on ground that corporation is mere alter ego of individual, it must be shown that stockholder's disregard of corporate entity made him mere instrumentality for transaction of own affairs, that there is unity of interest in ownership so that separate personalities of corporate and owners do not exist, and that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.

Reversed with directions.

Title: Lumpkin v. Envirodyne Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Purpose of alter ego doctrine is to prevent corporation that has acted fraudulently or unjustly from protecting itself from liability by shielding itself with protective mantle of corporate forum.
Document Preview: After settlement agreement was negotiated between former employees of division, predecessor employer, and successor employers in connection with employees' claim for unpaid pension benefits, employees brought action against successor employers' corporate parent under ERISA and Labor Management Relations Act.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, James B. Moran, Chief Judge, dismissed, and former employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cummings, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) ERISA's antialienation provision did not apply where central issue was whether agreement's release extended to parent corporation; (2) release was ambiguous on its face as a matter of law; (3) employees but not parent corporation could seek to invoke alter ego doctrine; and (4) employees' claim was governed by ten-year state statute of limitations governing actions on written contracts. Title: Coastal Shutters and Insulation, Inc. v. Derr
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego is only one basis for disregarding the corporation fiction, which will also be disregarded when fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud, is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation, is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, is used to circumvent statute, or is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong, or where corporation is undercapitalized.

On, inter alia, motions for summary judgment and motions to strike, the District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) material issues of fact precluded granting summary judgment in favor of proprietor on local's piercing corporate veil, RICO and common-law fraud claims; (2) material issue of fact precluded granting summary judgment in favor of proprietor on counterclaim for indemnification; (3) proprietor's §1983 and fraud claims were time barred; and (4) union was not entitled to Rule 11 sanctions. Title: In re Major Funding Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Two-step test is followed in determining whether corporation is alter ego of individual; first step is to determine if there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and second step is to determine if failure to disregard corporate form would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Trustee for Chapter 11 corporate debtor brought suit against alleged principal of debtor, seeking to recover for alleged principal's use of debtor's monies for what were believed to be nonbusiness purposes.  The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) bankruptcy trustee that had not sufficiently pled or proved he had standing to pursue cause of action to avoid transfer voidable by creditor holding unsecured claim was precluded from recovering by means of state law causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, negligence, assumpsit, and money had and received, and (2) evidence supported finding that principal controlled corporate debtor and its finances and had intent to defraud in transactions in which principal intentionally used corporate funds for his and/or his family's personal benefit, thus supporting avoidance of such transfers as fraudulent. Judgment for trustee.

Title: Zahra Spiritual Trust v. U.S.

Title: Shapoff v. Scull
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Alter ego liability is not predicated on defendant's intent to advance interests of corporation but, rather, it may be used only when its use will avoid fraud or injustice.

Title: Southern Environmental Group, Inc. v. Rosebud Landscape Gardeners, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Alter ego and piercing corporate veil theories are generally used for purpose of impressing individual with debts incurred by corporation.
Document Preview: Garnishment action was filed against monies owed by customers for landscaping services to landscaping corporation.  The State Court, Gwinnett County, Hoffman, J., after bench trial, dismissed garnishment on grounds that debtor corporation had ceased doing business after its assets and liabilities were acquired by new corporation.  Garnishor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that evidence that corporate fiction was maintained after new corporation was formed and acquired assets and liabilities of old corporation, which thereupon ceased doing business, was sufficient to support trial court's finding that the two corporations were not one and the same for purposes of garnishment of debt owed by first corporation, even though majority stockholder of corporations was same individual. Title: Derbyshire v. United Builders Supplies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, it must be shown that stockholders' disregard of corporate entity made it mere instrumentality for transaction of their own affairs, that there is such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of corporation and owners no longer exist, and that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Landlord sued corporations and individual corporate official to recover under a lease agreement and for damages to the leased premises.  The Muscogee State Court, Johnson, J., entered judgment on a jury verdict for landlord, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that: (1) the court erred in entering judgment without fulfilling its responsibility to decide the jurisdictional question raised by defendant's motion to dismiss; (2) it was proper to pierce the corporate veil to hold the individual defendant and the nonsignatory corporations liable under the lease; and (3) landlord could not recover attorney fees. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded with direction.

Document Preview: Buyer of computer software system brought breach of contract action against seller based on defects in system. The Court of Appeals, Eugene A. Headnote: A successful alter ego action results in a finding that defendants are personally liable for all corporate debts.

Headnote: Alter-ego doctrine, which is remedial in nature, is not applied to eliminate consequences of corporate operations, but to avoid inequitable results.
Document Preview: Permanent receiver moved for an order modifying the permanent injunction and order appointing permanent receiver to include various entities in the receivership which was established during an investigation of alleged securities law violations.  The District Court, Edward C. Reed, Jr., J., held that the corporate entities of various corporations would be disregarded and they would be included within the receivership where there were, among other things, commingling of funds and personal use of corporate assets. Permanent injunction and order appointing permanent receiver modified.

Title: E.B. Roberts Const. Co. v. Concrete Contractors, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" is means by which plaintiffs may pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders liable for the obligations of corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from judgment of the District Court, Adams County, James Delaney, J., finding breach of contract and awarding mechanic's lien on certain property.  The Court of Appeals, 664 P.2d 722, affirmed the finding of breach of contract and the mechanic's lien award, and certiorari was granted.  The Supreme Court, Lohr, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's summary finding that mechanic's lien claimed in lien statement was not excessive at the time of filing; (2) lien rights of mechanic's lien claimants were not forfeited, although amount of mechanic's lien claimed in lien statement was in excess of that actually awarded by trial court; and (3) third party was beneficiary of amended construction contract between general contractor and subcontractor and thus, was entitled to bring action for damages for lost profits sustained as result of contractor's breach of such contract. Affirmed.

Title: Mesler v. Bragg Management Co.
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: Two general requirements for piercing the corporate veil are that there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and if acts are treated as those of corporation alone, inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought personal injury action.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, John A. Shidler, J., granted defendant's motion for summary judgment, and plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Mosk, J., held that: (1) trial court should have allowed plaintiff to amend pleading to plead alter-ego theory, and (2) plaintiff's settlement with corporation did not bar plaintiff from proceeding against alter ego of corporation. Reversed. Lucas, J., filed a dissenting opinion.

Title: Standage v. Standage
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department A.
Headnote: Assets of validly formed corporation should be distinct and protected from debts of individual shareholders; however, where corporation is shown to be the alter ego or business conduit of a person, and where observing the corporate form would work an injustice, a court may properly pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Wife filed petition for dissolution of marriage.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. DR168725, Noel A. Fidel, J., entered judgment dissolving parties' marriage, and husband appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Greer, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in piercing corporate veil of parties' corporation on alter ego theory; (2) trial court improperly awarded attorney fees to wife as sanction for husband having prolonged proceeding and greatly increased its legal cost, where wife was able to pay her own fees; (3) trial court properly made nominal spousal maintenance award in view of potential tax liabilities of parties resulting from husband's failure to file tax returns for parties' corporation; and (4) trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding child support to wife from husband. Affirmed.

Title: Roy E. Thomas Const. Co. v. Arbs
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: The corporate entity will not be disregarded unless it is made to appear that there is such a unity that the separateness of the corporation has ceased to exist and the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the particular corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Purchasers of home brought deceptive trade practices action against corporate construction company and shareholder for breach of warranty to construct house in good and workmanlike manner.  The 141st District Court, Tarrant County, James E. Wright, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers, and builders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Joe Spurlock, II, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that defendant construction company breached warranty to construct house in good and workmanlike manner; (2) evidence supported jury's finding of cost to repair cracked foundation, bricks and mortar; (3) trial court did not err in awarding treble damages; (4) trial court did not err in awarding attorney fees to purchasers; and (5) there was no evidence to support jury's finding that corporate construction company had become alter ego of shareholder. Affirmed in part and reversed and reformed in part.

Title: In re Nash
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Finding of alter ego is not enough to disregard a corporate entity; it is also necessary to find that adherence to fiction of entity's separate existence would sanction a fraud or injustice in the particular circumstances.
Document Preview: Junior creditor challenged request by senior lien claimant to foreclose its security.  The Bankruptcy Court, George B. Title: Saeks v. Saeks
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: Concept of corporation being a separate entity from its shareholders is a legal fiction which will be disregarded under certain circumstances, such as where corporation has no separate identity from its shareholder or has no "mind" of its own, or where result of recognition of corporation would be inequitable, unjust, or result in injury, unjust loss, or derogation of rights of another party.
Document Preview: Former wife filed motion to show cause requesting that former husband be found in contempt for failure to pay permanent alimony due and for reasonable attorney fees.  The Court of Common Pleas, Montgomery County, entered judgment in favor of wife, and husband appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Weber, J., held that: (1) incorporated insurance agency was husband's alter ego and, thus, would not be recognized as a separate entity in calculating his income for permanent alimony purposes, and (2) attorney fees in the amount of $2,024 were properly awarded to wife after she successfully obtained lump-sum judgment for alimony arrearages. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Entech Systems Corp. v. Gaffney
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: If a sole shareholder fails to conduct business on a corporate footing in such a manner that corporation's identity cannot be distinguished from that of the shareholder, then corporation can be determined to be the "alter ego" of the shareholder, and shareholder will be personally liable for corporate debt.
Document Preview: Distributor of water treatment device brought breach of contract and negligent representation action against corporate manufacturer, its sole shareholder and second corporation allegedly controlled by that shareholder.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Joseph V. Dirosa, J., entered summary judgment for shareholder and second corporation, and distributor appealed. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Quad/Graphics, Inc. v. Fass
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Wisconsin.

Document Preview: Printer brought action to recover unpaid charges incurred by publishers of magazine. Title: Hock v. Sea Camper of New Orleans, Inc.

Title: Nebraska Engineering Co. v. Gerstner
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: In equity, corporate entity may be disregarded and held to be mere alter ego of a shareholder or shareholders in various circumstances where necessary to prevent fraud or other injustice.

The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., entered judgment for creditor, and shareholder appealed.  The Supreme Court, White, J., held that corporate entity would be disregarded as regarding creditor's action to recover the debt. Affirmed.

Title: White v. Jorgenson
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Proof of strict common-law fraud is not required to satisfy second prong of "alter ego" or "instrumentality" theory for imposing liability on individual shareholder; that prong of test requires showing of an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness which may be satisfied by evidence that corporate entity has been operated as a constructive fraud or in unjust manner.
Document Preview: Purchasers of new house brought suit for damages based on negligence, breach of contract, and breach of statutory warranties against corporate contractor and corporation's sole shareholder and officer.  The District Court, Dakota County, Robert J. Breunig, J., dismissed shareholder individually from lawsuit and entered judgment on jury verdict against corporate contractor, and purchasers appealed, claiming error in trial court's failure to pierce corporate veil.  The Supreme Court, Yetka, J., held that, proof of strict common-law fraud was not required to satisfy alter ego or instrumentality theory for imposing liability on individual shareholder; rather, evidence that corporate entity has been operated as constructive fraud or in unjust manner may satisfy requirement. Remanded.

Title: Amfac Mechanical Supply Co. v. Federer
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: For corporation to be accorded treatment as separate entity, it must exist and function as such and not be alter ego of person owning and controlling it and it cannot be used or ignored just to fit convenience of individual.

The District Court, Laramie County, Joseph F. Maier, J., granted defendants' motion to dismiss and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Raper, J., held that plaintiff established a prima facie case. Reversed and remanded.

Title: England Strohl/Denigris, Inc. v. Weiner
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and thus impose liability on the officers, corporate form must be found to be nothing more than a mere shell dominated and controlled by the individuals to carry on their own personal business.

Order accordingly.

Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When members fail to conduct a corporation on a separate footing, the court may ignore the corporate entity and hold individual members liable to third parties and, in such situations, the corporation is referred to as the "alter ego" of its members. LSA-C.C. arts. 435, 436.

Affirmed.

Title: Award Petroleum, Inc. v. Vantage Petroleum Corp.

Reversed and remanded.

Title: Marron v. H. O. Penn Machinery Co., Inc.

Title: Matter of Flanzbaum
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S. D. Florida.
Headnote: Where, although stock of corporation was reissued in the name of another, the debtor continued to run the corporation for his benefit, the corporation was the alter ego of the debtor.

Weaver, J., held that: (1) transfers of debtor's property to the corporation without consideration were fraudulent; (2) subsequent sale of all the stock in the corporation to another person did not affect the fraud; and (3) corporation was the alter ego of the debtor. Title: U.S. v. Healthwin-Midtown Convalescent Hospital and Rehabilitation Center, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C. D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, issues of alter ego do not lend themselves to strict rules and prima facie cases, and whether corporate veil should be pierced depends upon innumerable individual equities of each case.
Document Preview: United States brought suit to recover Medicare funds paid to provider of services under Medicare Act. The District Court, Maletz, J., of the United States Court of International Trade, sitting by designation, held that the individual defendant, the former president of the provider and owner of 50% of its stock, was proximately liable for the overpayments made to the provider, where individual defendant, had 50% interest in partnership which owned both realty in which provider's health care facility was located and furnishings used at that facility, had signed provider's checks without prior approval of another corporate officer, and in effect controlled corporation's operations and where provider was undercapitalized and individual defendant had caused provider's finances to become inextricably intertwined with both his personal finances and his other business holdings, thus making it appropriate to pierce corporation's veil. Headnote: In applying the alter ego doctrine, equity requires a disregard of the corporate fiction in holding the individual and dominating, officer shareholder liable for the corporate obligation, while respecting the corporate fiction in determining the validity of the underlying contract and the proper construction of its terms.

Title: Humphries v. Bray
Court: Court of Appeals of Arkansas.
Headnote: Conditions under which corporate entity may be disregarded or looked upon as alter ego of principal stockholder vary according to circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from the Circuit Court, Crittenden County, Gerald Brown, J., awarding workers' compensation benefits to the claimant. The Court of Appeals, Glaze, J., held that the corporation which was technically the employer of the claimant was merely the alter ego of the sole shareholder, and, therefore, the employees of the corporation could be combined with the shareholder's other employees for workers' compensation purposes. Affirmed.

Title: Gallagher v. Reconco Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: A corporate entity will be disregarded and the veil of limited liability pierced where it would otherwise present an obstacle to protection of private rights or where corporation is merely alter ego or business conduit of a governing or dominating personality.

The Appellate Court, Romiti, J., held that sole stockholder, as well as corporation, could be held liable for breach of contract. Affirmed.

Title: FMC Finance Corp. v. Murphree
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Common verbalization of the corporate disregard test is that there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder no longer exist, and adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would under the circumstances sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Suit was brought to enforce an unconditional personal guaranty contract of payment which covered payment of monies that a closely held Georgia corporation owed to plaintiff under an equipment lease agreement. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi, at Clarksdale, Orma R. Smith, J., directed a verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Sam D. Johnson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) warranty disclaimer language was conspicuous and thus validly negated any implied warranties on the part of plaintiff; (2) warranty disclaimer clause was not unconscionable; and (3) there was sufficient evidence to create a jury question on the corporate disregard issue raised by defendants, who attempted to assert against plaintiff the affirmative defense of its parent corporation's breach of manufacturer's warranty of repair or replacement of the leased buses. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Title: Sagebrush Sales Co. v. Strauss
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Personal liability is imposed on an individual stockholder rather than upon a corporation where the individual controls and manages the entity in such a manner that it becomes his alter ego.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller. The 68th Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Ray, J., 598 S.W.2d 1, affirmed in part and reversed in part. On appeal, the Supreme Court, Barrow, J., held that there was more than a scintilla of evidence to support jury findings that affairs of the various business entities, which were all owned and controlled by principal, were indistinguishable from his personal affairs and that he acted in such a manner as to lead seller to reasonably believe that the entities in question had reference to himself, and thus Court of Civil Appeals erred in sustaining principal's no evidence points and rendering a take-nothing judgment as to him. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Martin v. Pilot Industries
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, corporate entity may be properly disregarded and personal liability imposed upon shareholders of whom the corporation is the alter ego.
Document Preview: Buyer of business brought action against seller to recover for violations of the North Carolina Business Opportunity Sales Act. The United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, Hiram H. Ward, J., entered judgment in favor of the buyer, but declined to award attorney fees, and seller appealed. The Court of Appeals, James Dickson Phillips, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) the evidence demonstrated that there had been a sale of a business opportunity; (2) the Act was violated notwithstanding disavowal of the profit guarantee contained in the actual sales contract; (3) it was error to grant summary judgment imposing personal liability on shareholders of the seller; and (4) attorney fees were properly denied. Affirmed in part, vacated and remanded in part.

Title: United States Fire Ins. Co v. National Union Fire Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In order for the alter ego doctrine to apply there must be shown not only such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, but further that if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Robert P. Schifferman, J., determining insurers' obligations with respect to an aircraft accident, which occurred due to pilot's negligence and while pilot was engaged in business activities on behalf of corporation. The Court of Appeal, Potter, Acting P. J., held that nonowned aircraft coverage under policy which was expressly limited to vicarious liability of the corporation, of which aircraft pilot was the president, was secondary to policy, which covered pilot individually while operating a nonowned aircraft in the business of the corporation, despite contention that corporation was pilot's alter ego, where there was no evidence that the insurer of the corporation abused the corporate privilege or sought an inequitable advantage based upon the fiction of separate existence. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Phillips v. Montana Ed. Ass'n
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Corporate veil should not be utilized as protective device by those who employ corporate power or authority to serve their own ends.
Document Preview: Employee, whose employment had been terminated by corporation, appealed from order of the First District Court, Lewis and Clark County, Peter Meloy, J., granting motion for summary judgment on his count alleging malicious inducement of breach of contract. The Supreme Court, Harrison, J., held that board members and employees of corporation whose actions regarding termination of plaintiff's employment contract were within scope of their employment, designed without malice, and in furtherance of corporate interests were shielded from personal liability and not liable for malicious inducement of breach of contract. Affirmed. Shea, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Headnote: In order to disregard the corporate entity, there must be a finding that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and a finding that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: State, Dept. of Social and Health Services, Office of Support Enforcement v. Gerlack
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Corporation's separate entity will be respected when its officers conscientiously keep corporate affairs separate from their personal affairs unless a fraud or manifest injustice would be perpetrated upon those dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: Appeals were taken from judgment of the Superior Court, King County, Liem E. Tuai, J., which entered judgment in favor of Department of Social and Health Services and mother against father for unpaid child support and which denied collecting company's request for judgment. The Court of Appeals, Dore, J., held that: (1) state could collect child support payments from father while he was recipient of food stamps and medical care payments; (2) father could not maintain action against collecting company for wrongful garnishment where a judgment did exist; (3) father was not entitled to attorney fees; (4) no individual cause of action existed against the president of the collecting company for any improper service of copy of writ of garnishment; and (5) father was not entitled to jury trial on cross claim for wrongful garnishment. Affirmed.

Title: Matter of Twin Lakes Village, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: It is not a matter of "punishment" for the sloppy handling of intracorporate affairs which brings about an alter ego finding; instead, the court sees such sloppiness as inequitably rendering creditors prone to overlook a corporate formality to their eventual detriment; the controlling entity will therefore be estopped from denying that the faulty scenario they have drawn, or permitted to be drawn, is less than a legal reality when one of their creditors is injured by reliance on such a portrayal.
Document Preview: On debtors' objections to certain claims filed by a corporation's judgment creditor in the instant bankruptcy and Chapter XI arrangement proceedings, the Bankruptcy Court, Lloyd D. George, C. J., held, inter alia, that: (1) in respect to judgment creditor's claim that the debtors were obligated to the corporate judgment debtor and that the judgment creditor could therefore assert against the debtors the judgment debt owing it from the corporate entity, both a legal and a factual foundation was lacking to support claimant's right to recovery in bankruptcy court, and (2) claimant judgment creditor, having failed to establish by a preponderance of the evidence either the second or third elements of the McCleary alter ego test, could not satisfy its claim against any of the debtors, whom claimant alleged to be the alter ego of its corporate judgment debtor and to be liable to claimant for property transferred to them by claimant's judgment debtor. Objections sustained.

Title: State v. Nevitt
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: "Alter ego" theory requires that some showing be made that corporation was used by stockholder as sham or device in transaction in question and that equity should look through such sham to impose upon stockholder corporate obligation that was, in reality, his obligation.
Document Preview: State brought suit against corporation and shareholder for delinquent taxes of corporation. The County Court at Law, Dallas County, S. Bryan Moore, Jr., J., entered judgment in favor of shareholder and assessed costs to State, and State appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Carver, J., held that: (1) shareholder was not liable for corporation's taxes on alter ego, trust fund, or statutory theories; (2) no abuse of discretion was shown in trial court's failure to consolidate State's suit for 1975 taxes with subject suit for 1976 and 1977 taxes; (3) it was error to assess costs to State; and (4) no costs could be assessed to shareholder. Affirmed in part and vacated in part.

Title: St. Paul Ins. Companies v. Talladega Nursing Home, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In Alabama, alter ego of corporation may be either sole or controlling owner and, moreover, manager of operations may also be alter ego of corporation, and thus one insured, who was both controlling owner and general manager of nursing home, was properly found to be alter ego of nursing home corporation and her acts held to be tantamount to acts of the corporation in action by comprehensive nursing home liability insurer for declaratory judgment as to its duty to defend civil actions against insureds alleging slander, interference with business relations and violations of federal antitrust laws.
Document Preview: Action was brought by comprehensive nursing home liability insurer for declaratory judgment as to its duty to defend insureds in civil actions alleging slander, interference with business relations, and violations of the federal antitrust laws. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama at Birmingham, Seybourn H. Lynne, J., ruled that insurer was not obligated to defend underlying actions, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Godbold, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) Alabama public policy prohibits insuring against intentional wrongs; (2) allegations of underlying complaint, which alleged that insureds committed series of intentional acts calculated to prevent operation of competing nursing home, constituted intentional wrongs; and (3) insurer had no duty to defend where nothing indicated assertion of any theory of liability other than deliberate and intentional wrongs by insureds. Affirmed.

Title: Towers v. Titus

Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is equitable.

Title: Bonanza Hotel Gift Shop, Inc. v. Bonanza No. 2
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: The basic requisites for the application of the doctrine of alter ego and disregard of the fiction of separate corporate entities are that: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of a separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Affirmed.
