The Court of Appeal, Fourt, J., held that whether each of several shareholders of corporation would be liable on corporate obligation to bank as principals or partners under alter ego principle was question for jury. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: First Western Bank & Trust Co. v. Bookasta
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: To apply alter ego doctrine it is essential that showing be made of unity of interest and ownership and promotion of injustice by fiction of corporate separate existence.
Document Preview: Action upon corporation note by bank against corporation and several of its shareholders. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Ernest J. Zack, J., dismissed both counts of complaint and the bank appealed. The Court of Appeal, Fourt, J., held that whether each of several shareholders of corporation would be liable on corporate obligation to bank as principals or partners under alter ego principle was question for jury. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Henderson v. Security Mortg. & Finance Co.
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: When a corporation is so operated that it is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of declared public policy or statute, the corporate entity will be disregarded and the corporation and the shareholder treated as one and the same person.
Document Preview: Action to recover double the amount of usury paid by plaintiffs to defendants, and for a judgment declaring plaintiffs to be owners of a certain house and lot, and directing defendants to make a deed therefor to plaintiffs. The Superior Court, Guilford County, Walter E. Crissman, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Lake, J., held that judgment declaring plaintiffs to be owners of land in question and requiring defendants to execute a deed to plaintiffs was proper where combination of plaintiffs' absolute deed to defendants, and a so-called rent agreement, was in effect a mortgage, and where defendant engineered a purported foreclosure with knowledge that there was no default in payment of indebtedness secured by combination of absolute deed and so-called rent agreement. Modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Manning v. State
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Austin.
Headnote: Where corporation is used by individuals in control of it as mere dummy for their operations, corporate veil may be pierced to effect justice and to hold managers personally responsible. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 8.18, par. C; V.A.T.S. Insurance Code, art. 8.16.
Document Preview: Attorney General brought suit in name of state in nature of quo warranto to oust insurance operation conducted by defendants in name of foreign corporation, and for receivership and injunction. The 53rd District Court, Travis County, Herman Jones, J., entered judgment for state and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, O'Quinn, J., held that president and salesman of corporation who acted as partners to conduct insurance business in name of corporation without certificate of authority from state were subject to assessment of penalties against them individually and could not avail themselves of defense of doctrine of corporate entity. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Olympic Capital Corp. v. Newman
Court: United States District Court C.D. California.
Headnote: Alter ego is limited to situation where there is reason to disregard a corporate entity to reach individual, and it has no applicability in disregarding existence of individual to reach corporate assets.
Document Preview: Action arising out of promissory note executed by individual defendant. The corporate defendant filed motion for dismissal or, in the alternative, for summary judgment. The individual defendant also filed motion for dismissal of amended complaint and alternatively, to transfer case to another district. The District Court, Real, J., held that where sale of promissory note of individual defendant was completed as combination of negotiations and acts in Colorado, Oklahoma and Texas, and individual defendant could neither be found nor did he transact business within Central District of California, action commenced in California District Court arising out of the note transaction based on alleged Securities Act violations was dismissed on individual defendant's motion on ground that venue was improper. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Holahan v. Henderson
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: The "doctrine of alter ego" passes liability of corporation onto owner of corporation who has treated corporation's affairs as his own.
Document Preview: Actions by trustee of corporation in bankruptcy to recover certain funds expended by corporation before its bankruptcy. The District Court, Edwin F. Hunter, Jr., J., held that explanation given by president of bankrupt corporation and his assistant for loss of corporate funds that president had written $103,000 in checks from corporation to assistant to enable latter to buy oil and gas leases for corporation, that assistant cashed all checks so as to be able to pay cash for leases and that assistant left cash in home which, together with cash, was destroyed by fire was not so incredible as to warrant subjecting president and assistant to liability to trustee in bankruptcy on theory that money had been stolen from corporation. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Oak Ridge Auto Repair Service v. City Finance Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Section.
Headnote: Separate entity will be quickly disregarded upon a showing that corporation is a mere sham or dummy or where necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: Suit in detinue by finance company. The Circuit Court, Anderson County, John M. Kelly, J., gave judgment against individual defendant, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Carney, J., held that where automobile repair service was at most a mere instrumentality or agency of individual defendant, who was sole stockholder, and it did not appear that automobile repair service did any acts separate and apart from the acts of its sole stockholder and owner, individual defendant could not use the corporate entity as a shield for thwarting finance company in foreclosure of its chattel trust, as to which individual defendant was chargeable with constructive notice. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Long v. McGlon
Court: United States District Court D. South Carolina, Columbia Division.
Headnote: Where interest of corporation and dominant shareholder are identical one is the alter ego of other and corporate form may be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action by trustee of bankrupt corporation against sole shareholders thereof, who were also the directors and officers, to hold them personally liable for debts of corporation. On motion to dismiss, the District Court, Hemphill, J., held that trustee of bankrupt corporation was entitled to bring suit to impose liability on individual defendants who were sole shareholders, officers and directors of corporation for debts of corporation on ground that defendants had at all times treated corporation as if it were a proprietorship or partnership, as trustee represented creditors as well as bankrupt corporation and there was no prejudice to corporate creditors by seeking to hold individual shareholders of nominal but insolvent corporation liable for its debts. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ivy v. Plyler
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Doctrine of alter ego is based upon misuse of corporation by individual for wrongful or inequitable personal purposes.
Document Preview: Action against director of corporation for recovery of rentals under contracts to lease oil well drilling equipment. The Superior Court, Kern County, Paul R. Borton, J., rendered judgment for lessor and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeal, Stone, J., held that director's defense of discharge in bankruptcy failed because director, as incorporator and secretary of corporation with knowledge of corporation's liability under contracts, misappropriated corporate funds to his personal use at time when corporation was insolvent. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ivy v. Plyler
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Under doctrine of "alter ego", court merely disregards corporate entity and holds individual responsible for acts knowingly and intentionally done in the name of corporation.
Document Preview: Action against director of corporation for recovery of rentals under contracts to lease oil well drilling equipment. The Superior Court, Kern County, Paul R. Borton, J., rendered judgment for lessor and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeal, Stone, J., held that director's defense of discharge in bankruptcy failed because director, as incorporator and secretary of corporation with knowledge of corporation's liability under contracts, misappropriated corporate funds to his personal use at time when corporation was insolvent. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Manney & Co. v. Texas Reserve Life Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Dallas.
Headnote: To establish that corporation is alter ego of stockholders it is necessary to show that stockholders disregarded entity of corporation thereby making it mere conduit for transaction of their own private business and that separate individualities of corporation and its stockholders do not exist.
Document Preview: Derivative action by corporate stockholder in insurance company against insurance company's successor corporation and officers of insurance company and successor corporation and development corporation. The District Court, Dallas County, James F. McCarthy, J., rendered summary judgment and stockholder appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Claude Williams, J., held that where defendants, majority stockholders in insurance company, were president and chairman of the board of insurance company and were also majority stockholders and president and chairman of board in development corporation and of insurance company's successor corporation, and directors of development corporation and insurance corporation effected purchase of $1,000,000 bond of development corporation by insurance company, and evidence showed that development corporation was not alter ego of president and chairman and that it was solvent and not in default on bond and that merger and loan were legal, no damage to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Long Falls Realty Co. v. Anchor Elec. Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Dallas.
Headnote: Alter ego corporations are not in themselves illegal.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of corporation brought garnishment proceeding against trustee who held surplus funds from mortgage foreclosure sale and impleaded holder of recorded judgment lien and assignee of recorded deed of trust lien. The District Court, Dallas County, Julien C. Hyer, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff and for assignee, and holder appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Dixon, C .J., held that corporation's actual physical possession of realty prior to recording of judgment against it and at all times thereafter until foreclosure sale put holder on notice to inquire into corporation's claim of title and where holder made no inquiry, it was not entitled to surplus funds over assignee. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Linco Services, Inc. v. DuPont
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: To disregard corporate entity and hold individual liable on ground that corporation is his alter ego it is necessary that there be unity of interest and ownership and that separate personalities no longer exist, and that there would be inequitable result by treating acts as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: Action against corporation and two individuals on alter ego theory on note made by corporation. The Superior Court, County of San Mateo, Frank W. Rose, J., rendered judgment against all defendants and one of the individual defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Draper, P. J., held that where appellant by written agreement, active participation and guaranty to bank clothed corporation with indicia of financial stability, secured its reentry into active business after dormancy caused by financial weakness, entered upon active participation in its affairs as director and officer, from which positions he attempted to resign when finances toppled, and he shared responsibility for failure of corporation to issue any stock, court could properly hold him individually liable on a note given to corporation in connection with purchase of an airplane on ground that corporation was his alter ego. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Platt v. Billingsley
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Two criteria exist for determining that alter ego doctrine is applicable: (1) such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individuals no longer exist, and (2) inequitable result from treatment of acts as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: Action to hold stockholders personally liable for corporate indebtedness. The Superior Court, Orange County, Raymond Thompson, J., rendered judgment for remodeling contractor, and stockholders appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Stone, J., held that evidence supported finding that corporation was influenced, dominated, and controlled by sellers of part of stock and by buyer thereof who were sued on theory of alter ego and whose corporation was under-capitalized at all times. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Platt v. Billingsley
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is essentially one of equity which rests largely upon facts peculiar to each case.
Document Preview: Action to hold stockholders personally liable for corporate indebtedness. The Superior Court, Orange County, Raymond Thompson, J., rendered judgment for remodeling contractor, and stockholders appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Stone, J., held that evidence supported finding that corporation was influenced, dominated, and controlled by sellers of part of stock and by buyer thereof who were sued on theory of alter ego and whose corporation was under-capitalized at all times. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Rosen v. E. C. Losch, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: One element necessary before invoking doctrine of alter ego is unity of interest between corporation and its shareholders.
Document Preview: Proceeding on appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Jerold E. Weil, J., against individual plaintiffs on defendant sub-subcontractor's cross complaint for its share of profits under written contract for installation of gas and water systems at air base. The District Court of Appeal, Lillie, J., held that fact that agreement was captioned subcontracting agreement did not of itself show that joint venture was not contemplated by parties thereto and thus did not establish error on part of trial court in otherwise construing such agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Evans v. General Ins. Co. of America
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Unless owner or owners of all or nearly all of corporate stock themselves ignore corporate entity, or corporation is shown to be a mere fiction or false front set up by owner or owners of all or nearly all of the corporate stock to conceal his or their fraudulent business operations individually, corporate entity will not be pierced or ignored in order to hold such stockholders accountable under the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Action by truck liability insurer against corporate insured, insured's president-majority stockholder, and operator of insured's truck for declaratory judgment that insurer had no obligation to defend insured or operator in action brought against them by president-stockholder for injuries received when struck by truck. The District Court, Dallas County, Paul Peurifoy, J., entered declaratory judgment for insurer, and president-stockholder appealed. The Court of Civil Appellas, Dixon, C. J., held that president-majority stockholder was not an employee within liability policy provision that insurance for other than named insured does not apply to an employee with respect to an injury to another employee, and that evidence failed to sustain court's finding that injury arose from president-stockholder's employment as insured corporation's employee within exclusion provision of policy. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McDonald & Co. v. Kemper
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: If individual owner of corporation uses it only for individual purposes, they will be considered to all intents and purposes one and the same.
Document Preview: Action by realtor against president of corporation to recover commission for procuring a buyer for property of corporation. The District Court, Tarrant County, Harold Craik, J., entered judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Renfro, J., held that sale of all stock by sole stockholder to buyer secured by realtor, rather than sale of corporate property as provided in exclusive written agency contract, did not defeat broker's right to commission on sale. Reversed and rendered in part; reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: People v. Clauson
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Effect of applying alter ego theory is to treat alter ego and instrumentality as synonymous and not as separate juristic entities in order to avoid inequitable results.
Document Preview: Actions against individual stockholders of corporation to recover amount of delinquent sales tax liability incurred by corporation. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Leon T. David, J., sustained defendants' demurrers to complaints without leave to amend, and appeals by the state were consolidated. The District Court of Appeal, Roth, P. J., held that statute providing that actions to collect delinquent taxes may be brought within three years after last recording of delinquency certificate was binding on individual stockholders, who exercised complete control and owned substantially all assets of corporations, and who state sought to hold liable, under alter ego theory, for amount of delinquent sales tax liability incurred by corporation, even though tax delinquency certificates failed to name individuals as taxpayers, and, once true identity of individuals as those using corporate structures as their alter egos was established, certificates of delinquency filed by state were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Neese v. Fireman's Fund Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern Section.
Headnote: Where corporation is mere sham or dummy, or is being used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or protect fraud, corporate entity will be disregarded.
Document Preview: In a case which originated as a general creditor's bill, the Chancery Court, Hamilton County, Ray L. Brock, Jr., Chancellor, allowed all claims against surety on statutory Real Estate Agent's and Salesman's Bond except that of bankruptcy trustee, and the trustee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cooper, J., held that where domination of both parent and subsidiary corporation by majority stockholder and principal executive officer of both corporations was so complete that neither had any mind, will or existence of its own, relationship was such that they were to be treated as single entity, for purposes of parent's trustee's claim on subsidiary's bond. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Auer v. Frank
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Basic requirements for application of doctrine of disregard of corporate entity are that there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist and that, if acts are treated as those of corporation alone, inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Action wherein plaintiff general contractor sought to hold individual defendants responsible for obligations incurred by the corporate defendant on a construction contract. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Alameda County, C. Stanley Wood, Judge pro tem., in favor of the individual defendants, the general contractor appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Molinari, J., held that the application of the alter ego doctrine was an issue in the case and that a finding of the court upon it was implied. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: National Bond Finance Co. v. General Motors Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under "instrumentality" or "alter ego" rule there must be complete domination as to transaction in question, fraud or injustice must result from the use of such control, and plaintiff's injury must be a proximate result of control and breach of duty of dominating corporation.
Document Preview: Action for actual and punitive damages growing out of transactions between plaintiff and an automobile dealer doing business in Illinois involving the purchase of conditional sales contracts for sale of motor vehicles. The District Court, Duncan, J., held, inter alia, that evidence regarding relationship between finance company which purchased automobile conditional sales contracts, the automobile manufacturer and automobile dealer did not justify piercing of corporate veil of dealer and holding the manufacturer liable for actions and conduct of dealer's president and of dealer so as to render manufacturer liable to company for losses sustained. Judgment for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Design Associates, Inc. v. Welch
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Acts and obligations of corporation can be considered those of individual only if (1) individual is sole owner and manager and there is such unity of interest and ownership that individuality or separateness of person and corporation has ceased; and (2) facts are such that to deny individual liability would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Suit on contract for performance of architectural services and on claim of lien. The Superior Court, Nevada County, Vernon Stoll, J., gave judgment for defendants and the plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Pierce, P. J., held that where the plaintiff pleaded a cause of action on contract with an individual and did not join the corporation he could not, on failing to prove a contract with the individual, recover on facts incidentally appearing which, if properly put in issue, might have justified disregard of the corporate entity to hold the individual. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Dashew v. Dashew Business Machines, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is resorted to only when necessary to avoid grave injustice.
Document Preview: Former wife's suit to rescind property settlement agreement, set aside portions of interlocutory divorce judgment, to have adjudicated community property stock held by husband in defendant corporation or for damages award. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Joseph W. Vickers, J., granted the corporation's summary judgment motion and the plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Shinn, P. J., held that corporation which held no property in which plaintiff, former wife of its president and principal stockholder claimed interest, which was not a party to property settlement agreement and under no obligation imposed by agreement, which had no interest adverse to former wife and which did not at any time authorize president or accountant to act for it in negotiation of spouses' property settlement could not be properly made a party defendant. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tarter, Webster & Johnson, Inc. v. Windsor Developers, Inc.
Court: Appellate Department, Superior Court, San Diego County, California.
Headnote: General purpose of alter ego theory is to look through fiction of corporation and hold individuals doing business in name of corporation liable for its debts in cases where it should be so held in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Action by wholesale lumber company to foreclose mechanic's liens on residence properties constructed by developer. The San Diego Municipal Court, Robert O. Staniforth, J., rendered judgment for the wholesaler, and the developer appealed. The Superior Court held that wholesaler, which furnished loads for individual houses to retailer which supplied developer's framing contractor, was not entitled to mechanic's liens on individual residence properties even if retailer and framing contractor were but alter ego of individuals organizing both corporations, where neither corporation nor individuals who organized them were parties to foreclosure action. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McKee v. Peterson
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded where there is such unity of ownership and interest that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and where if acts relied on by plaintiff are treated as those of corporation alone an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Automobile seller's action against chattel mortgagee and others. The Superior Court, County of San Mateo, Edmund Scott, J., entered a judgment in favor of the mortgagee and the seller and one of the individual defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Bray, P. J., held that seller of automobile to dealer, which gave check that was dishonored, was estopped to claim ownership of automobile as against bona fide mortgagee who had relied on indicia of ownership, except possession of automobile, furnished by seller to dealer which mortgagee had no reason to suspect would give a check that would be dishonored. Judgment reversed and cause remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Associated Vendors, Inc. v. Oakland Meat Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Two requirements to piercing of the corporate veil are that there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Action by a landlord to recover rent. The Superior Court, Alameda County, Monroe Friedman, J., entered judgment adverse to landlord and it appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Molinari, J., held that evidence sustained finding that tenant corporation was not the alter ego of other corporate defendant or officers and stockholders thereof, even though there was a certain mutuality of stock ownership. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McLaughlin v. L. Bloom Sons Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is founded in equity and its application does not depend on prior decisions involving factual situations which appear to be similar.
Document Preview: Union's action for declaratory judgment that the new defendant corporation was the alter ego of the old defendant corporation for the purposes of collective bargaining agreement. The Superior Court, County of Santa Clara Robert F. Peckham, J., entered a judgment for the union and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Agee, J., held that it was not an abuse of discretion to apply the alter ego doctrine to the new corporation which was controlled by the same individuals as the old corporation that had signed a collective bargaining agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McCombs v. Rudman
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Function and purpose of alter ego doctrine is to prevent injustice.
Document Preview: Action by electrical contractor against general contractor and others for amount due for electrical work in housing subdivision and for foreclosure on mechanics' lien. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Ray P. Brockmann, J., in favor of electrical contractor against general contractor alone, and denying foreclosure of lien, the electrical contractor appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Shinn, P. J., held that evidence established that general contracting company was the alter ego of sole stockholder, who served as president and who turned over all of his individual business to the company upon incorporation and conducted the affairs of the corporation as principal officer, rendering president liable for amounts owing by company to electrical contractor. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Kazutoff v. Wahlstrom
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: In order to disregard corporate entity, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist and that adherence to fiction of separate existence would promote fraud or injustice, and on second score, it is sufficient that it appear that recognition of acts as those of corporation only will produce inequitable results.
Document Preview: Action by buyers of an allegedly unsatisfactorily built swimming pool against the bankrupt corporate builder's stockholders, who had formerly operated the business as a partnership, for rescission, breach of contract, and piercing of the corporate veil. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Bayard Rhone, J., entered a judgment for the defendants, and the plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, McMurray, J. pro tem, held that failure to list as an asset in bankruptcy proceedings the balance owed by the buyers did not estop the stockholders, who were not shown to be parties to the bankruptcy proceedings, from asserting the corporate entity of the builder. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: United M.P.B. Novelty Mfg. Corp. v. Sinensky
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Corporation would be bound by its predecessor's commitments if it was the alter ego of its predecessor.
Document Preview: Action for injunctive relief against the defendants' picketing of the plaintiff's place of business. The plaintiff moved for a temporary injunction and the defendants cross moved to dismiss and for a summary judgment on the pleadings. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Kings County, Louis B. Heller, J., held that a question of fact existed as to whether there was violence and threats of violence, precluding dismissal on affidavits or summary judgment for the defendants on the pleadings, and also precluding the granting of a temporary injunction. Motions denied; temporary injunction denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: City Bank Farmers Trust Co. v. Macfadden
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To treat a corporation as the mere alter ego of a stockholder or member and thus destroy its immunity from liability for his debts of personal obligations is to disregard its existence as a separate legal entity.
Document Preview: Action for a judicial settlement of the account of plaintiff as trustee under a deed of trust. From an interlocutory judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Edgar J. Nathan, Jr., J., 25 Misc.2d 125, 198 N.Y.S.2d 782, the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Eager, J., held that the evidence did not establish that transfers of funds and property by husband in his lifetime to a foundation were fraudulent as to the former wife or in violation of the Debtor and Creditor Law and that a prior New Jersey judgment was not res judicata. Judgment modified. Stevens and McNally, JJ., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Macpherson v. Eccleston
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded only where there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist.
Document Preview: Purchasers' action against vendors and others predicated upon an asserted breach of the vendors' agreement to include in any other conveyances of land in the area restrictive covenants precluding use for service station purposes. The breach was allegedly made by a sale of land by a corporate defendant in which one of the vendors owned substantially all of the stock. The Superior Court, County of Contra Costa, Hugh H. Donovan, J., rendered a judgment for the defendants and the plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Draper, J., held that the single uncontradicted fact that one vendor owned substantially all the stock of the corporation was not enough to require disregard of the corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Claremont Press Pub. Co. v. Barksdale
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: With regard to corporations, the alter ego doctrine applies only when (1) the individual not only influences and governs the corporation but there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality or separateness of the person and corporation have ceased, and (2) the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would under the particular circumstances sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action against individual who, along with associate, had organized corporation for purposes of publishing newspaper, which was not shown to have been transferred to corporation, to recover for services rendered in printing of the newspaper. The Superior Court, County of Alameda, William J. McGuiness, J., found that individual and associate were partners and associates doing business as newspaper and as the corporation and rendered judgment against individual, and individual appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Draper, J., held that where individual, who had been advised that at least $10,000 capital would be required for newspaper, and had contributed only $500 to capital, would have been permitted to secure benefit of printing services without liability therefor if separate entities of corporation and individual were recognized, and corporation never issued stock or secured permit to do so, but individual sold his interest in the corporation, and there was contradicted evidence...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Claremont Press Pub. Co. v. Barksdale
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Requirement that to apply alter ego doctrine the facts must be such that adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would under the particular circumstances sanction a fraud or promote injustice, is satisfied when refusal to recognize unity of corporation and individual will bring about inequitable results.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wincar Welders v. Leebrick
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The conditions under which corporate entity may be disregarded, or the corporation be regarded as the alter ego of the stockholders, necessarily vary according to the circumstances in each case, inasmuch as the doctrine is essentially an equitable one, and therefore that question is particularly within the province of the trial court.
Document Preview: Action by copartnership on common counts for goods, wares, merchandise and services, and on assigned claim of another for goods, wares, merchandise and services, against six defendants, of which Nos. 5 and 6 were corporations. From judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Bruce Findlay, J., against corporate defendant No. 6 and in favor of the other defendants, copartnership appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Fourt, J., held that where counsel for appellant prepared findings, and there was no express finding upon issue whether individuals were alter ego of corporate defendant No. 6, appellants could not complain of court's alleged oral ruling that court would not consider that issue. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Smith v. Royal Mfg. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: In order to invoke the doctrine of "alter ego", there must be a unity of interest and ownership of such a nature that separate individual and corporate personalities do not exist, and that if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Garnishment proceeding wherein garnishor sought to recover from garnishees an amount held under a liquidated damages provision of a contract with judgment debtor. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, Clarence W. Morris, J., rendered judgment for garnishor, and garnishees appealed. The District Court of Appeal, McGoldrick, J. pro tem., held that evidence supported finding that liquidated damages provision, in a contract for sale of coffee machines to judgment debtor, was invalid as a penalty. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Five Star Transfer & Terminal Warehouse Corp. v. Flusche
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Where a supposed or ostensible corporation is a mere dummy under the management of individuals who control such corporation in the form of a partnership, the corporation and partnership are mere alter egos, and the corporate veil may pierced to effectively do justice to an injured party.
Document Preview: Action for $18,810 by buyer of stock in corporation, the business of which was conducted by a partnership and the assets of which were owned and held by partnership, for rescission and damages resulting from allegedly fraudulent representations by partners that the business entity was a solvent going corporation. The District Court, Dallas County, A. R. Stout, J., gave judgment for buyer and corporation and one of the partners appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Fanning, J., held that jury's answer to special issue, that value of stock, at the time of delivery to buyer, was $18,810, was unnecessary to disposition of case in view of fact that evidence established that purchaser had been damaged by paying $18,810 for stock in a corporation that had no assets and was not a going concern, and trial court did not err in disregarding jury's answer to special issue and permitting purchaser to pursue remedy of rescission and damages. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Feldman v. Capitol Piece Dye Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: A corporation which was wholly owned and controlled by a man and his son was but the alter ego of its owners and the knowledge of such owners was the knowledge of the corporation.
Document Preview: Action by trustee in bankruptcy to recover funds of bankrupt corporation alleged to have been preferentially or fraudulently transferred and the value of inventory allegedly converted from bankrupt. The District Court, Bryan, J., held, inter alia, that where factor, to which bankrupt corporation had assigned all its accounts receivable, paid 65 per cent of amount of antecedent indebtedness of bankrupt corporation for inventory purchased from another corporation owned and controlled by two officers of bankrupt corporation and reimbursed itself for such payment from proceeds of assigned accounts receivable, such transaction resulted in a preferential transfer under Bankruptcy Act, section 60, sub. b, 11 U.S.C.A., section 96, sub. b, for which both transferee corporation and its individual owners were liable. Judgment in accordance with opinion in favor of plaintiff except as against defendant bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Talbot v. Fresno-Pacific Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: Before a corporation's acts and obligations can be recognized as those of a particular person, and vice versa, it must appear that the corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of such person and corporation has ceased, and that the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of separate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action to recover the price of lumber sold. From a judgment of the Superior Court of Fresno County, Matt Goldstein, J., the individual defendant appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Griffin, P. J., held that where the individual defendant's liability was based on the alter ego theory, evidence sustained findings that the corporate entity should be disregarded and that the corporation should be regarded as a mere alter ego of the defendant and that defendant was personally liable. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Shaffer v. Buxbaum
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Although ordinarily a corporation in its legal capacity cannot be inquired into collaterally or questioned by a private citizen in a controversy between it and him, such rule does not preclude an examination into the facts to ascertain the identity of a person who uses the name of a corporation for his own purposes and to fix liability for the ostensible corporate acts upon him.
Document Preview: Action to foreclose a mechanic's lien for labor. Defendants counterclaimed for damages. The Seventh District Court, Dawson County, W. R. Flachsenhar, J., entered judgment for defendants on their counterclaim, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Nat Allen, District Judge, held that evidence sustained finding that plaintiff, with intent to cheat and defraud defendants, caused a contract for construction of an addition to defendants' dwelling to be made in the name of a corporate construction company, a family corporation organized by plaintiff, and that such contract was in fact the contract of plaintiff. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Hyde v. Hyde
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: While, for ordinary purposes, a corporation is regarded as a legal entity, separate and distinct from its shareholders, entity may be disregarded where corporation is mere alter ego or business conduit of individual.
Document Preview: Action commenced by father against son for breach of contract whereunder father transferred to son shares in family corporation and whereunder it was agreed that father would receive stipulated monthly payments, but son contended that subsequent agreement had, by novation, superseded contract on which action was predicated and that father had received all that he was entitled to under subsequent agreement. The Circuit Court of Minnehaha County, George A. Rice, J., rendered judgment on jury verdict for plaintiff and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Roberts, J., held that evidence on issue of whether son had abused relation of trust and confidence that existed between himself and his father who was 87 years at time of transaction and who had no independent advice by inducing him to enter into subsequent agreement was for jury. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Shamrock Oil & Gas Co. v. Ethridge
Court: United States District Court D. Colorado.
Headnote: When the facts demonstrate that corporation is merely alter ego or business conduit of its governing or dominating personality, courts are not hesitant to pierce corporate veil and look to the ultimate person in order to regard them as one for the purpose of preventing an injustice.
Document Preview: Replevin action. The District Court, Arraj, J., held that where operator of oil well drilling rig sold his rig to corporation and operator continued to operate rig and corporation had no assets apart from rig and no business apart from such operation and operator completely controlled and dominated corporation and was in effect its sole owner, corporation was mere dummy corporation and was alter ego of operator with no existence apart from him, and consequently corporation was bound by sheriff's sale of portions of rig in satisfaction of judgment against operator. Judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Shamrock Oil & Gas Co. v. Ethridge
Court: United States District Court D. Colorado.
Headnote: The effect of applying the alter ego doctrine is that corporation and person who dominates it are treated as one person, so that any act committed by one is attributed to both, and if either is bound by contract, judgment, or otherwise, both are equally bound; however, this is done only for the purpose of adjudging rights and liabilities of the parties in the case.
Document Preview: Replevin action. The District Court, Arraj, J., held that where operator of oil well drilling rig sold his rig to corporation and operator continued to operate rig and corporation had no assets apart from rig and no business apart from such operation and operator completely controlled and dominated corporation and was in effect its sole owner, corporation was mere dummy corporation and was alter ego of operator with no existence apart from him, and consequently corporation was bound by sheriff's sale of portions of rig in satisfaction of judgment against operator. Judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Larson v. Western Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Where corporation is the mere alter ego or business conduit of an individual, the corporate entity may be disregarded, but only for the purpose of adjudging rights and liabilities of parties in the particular case, and corporate entity is regarded for all other purposes.
Document Preview: Action by purchasers of realty under contract for deed against vendor corporation and its principal stockholder and managing officer for appointment of a receiver and damages for misrepresentation in sale of realty, wherein defendants, by counterclaim, sought foreclosure of contract for deed. The Circuit Court of Minnehaha County, Roy D. Burns, J., entered judgment appointing a receiver and awarding damages, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Bogue, J., held, inter alia, that when purchasers of realty received notice that vendor corporation had defaulted in its payments on mortgage against the realty, purchasers properly instituted action for appointment of receiver and that failure to make one monthly payment on contract for deed until appointment of receiver did not entitle vendor corporation to invoke acceleration clause of contract and foreclose contract for deed. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: R. B. General Trucking, Inc. v. Auto Parts & Service, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Where a corporation is the mere alter ego or business conduit of a person, or the affairs of a dominant person have been commingled with those of a corporation, the corporate entity will be disregarded when its recognition would protect fraud.
Document Preview: Action by corporation to enjoin defendant from taking steps to collect a judgment from plaintiff. The Circuit Court, Milwaukee County, Ronold A. Drechsler, J., entered summary judgment for defendant and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Fairchild, J., held that where prior action was for goods sold, civil court had jurisdiction to amend judgment against individual defendant so as to name such defendant as sole trader doing business under name of plaintiff corporation which had entered general appearance in hearing on order to show cause why title of action should not be amended, and judgment of civil court could not be collaterally attacked. Affirmed. Broadfoot, Currie, and Steinle, JJ., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Frank McCleary Cattle Co. v. Sewell
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: In order to invoke "alter ego" doctrine, corporation must be influenced and governed by person asserted to be its alter ego, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and facts must be such that adherence to fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice, though actual fraud need not be shown.
Document Preview: Proceedings supplemental to execution. From an order of the Sixth Judicial District Court, Humboldt County, Frank B. Gregory, P. J., making assets of another corporation available to execution upon the judgment, that corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Merrill, J., held that appellant corporation, which was owned by sole owners of judgment debtor corporation and to which all assets of judgment debtor corporation had been transferred, was properly treated as alter ego of judgment debtor corporation and that its assets were properly made available to execution upon the judgment without an independent action against transferee corporation, but that judgment should be corrected to run against transferee corporation. Order affirmed and matter remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Engineering Service Corp. v. Longridge Inv. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Application of the alter ego doctrine does not depend upon plea or proof of fraud, and it is enough if the recognition of the two entities as separate would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: Action by engineering company to foreclose mechanics' lien on realty for services performed and to hold individuals personally liable for corporate obligations. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Lloyd S. Nix, J., entered judgment for company and some of the individual defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Ashburn, J., held that individuals were personally liable for obligation incurred in name of individuals as well as corporation ostensibly formed for purpose of carrying on business of selling subdivision lots but which was actually created for income tax advantages. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Employer's Liability Assur. Corp. v. Lunt
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: Corporate fiction will be disregarded when corporation is, in fact, alter ego of one or a few individuals and when observance of corporate form would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action by seller against corporate purchaser, officers of corporation, and its surety for unpaid balance on purchase price of farm produce. From adverse judgment of the Superior Court, Greenlee County, Porter Murry, J., the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Struckmeyer, J., held that under act requiring commission merchants or agents to furnish a bond for use and benefit of any consignor of farm products, protection of bond giving right of action thereon to any person injured by violation of provisions of act or failure of any person licensed under act to comply with regulations thereunder was limited to persons referred to in recital portion of bond, which was a commission merchant or agent, and surety was not liable for default of principal while acting in capacity of dealer. Affirmed in part and reversed in part with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Employer's Liability Assur. Corp. v. Lunt
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: Where business operated by husband was incorporated and husband, wife, and son became principal officers, directors and stockholders of corporation and controlled corporation's assets and its operations, and business engaged in by corporation was same business that husband had conducted prior to incorporation and its theory of operation, office location, office equipment, post office address and telephone number were identical, the family was the alter ego of the corporation.
Document Preview: Action by seller against corporate purchaser, officers of corporation, and its surety for unpaid balance on purchase price of farm produce. From adverse judgment of the Superior Court, Greenlee County, Porter Murry, J., the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Struckmeyer, J., held that under act requiring commission merchants or agents to furnish a bond for use and benefit of any consignor of farm products, protection of bond giving right of action thereon to any person injured by violation of provisions of act or failure of any person licensed under act to comply with regulations thereunder was limited to persons referred to in recital portion of bond, which was a commission merchant or agent, and surety was not liable for default of principal while acting in capacity of dealer. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Shafford v. Otto Sales Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The two requirements for disregarding corporate entity are that there should be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and that if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Salesman's action to recover commissions on sales of products for corporation. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, Clarence W. Morris, J., entered judgment against corporate as well as individual defendant the latter appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Fred B. Wood, J., held that evidence was sufficient to justify determination that corporation was merely after ego of individual defendant against whom judgment would be entered. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Hudson v. Wylie
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: No inquiry could be made into question of corporate alter ego if no fraud or inequitable proposition was being shielded thereby.
Document Preview: Proceeding brought by bankruptcy trustee to recover profits earned by bankrupt and a coadventurer under a construction contract. The United States District Court for the Southern District of California, Central Division, William C. Mathes, J., granted the relief sought, and an appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Ross, District Judge, held that even though divisible joint adventure agreement required bankrupt to procure and perform contracts with Commodity Credit Corporation for construction of grain bins, and recited that the availability of bankrupt for such time as might be necessary to procure and perform such construction contracts was an inducing consideration, requirement therein that other adventurer supply management and all labor and material made it clear that real consideration running from bankrupt was his procurement of construction contracts; and held that since the construction contract in question had been procured prior to adjudication, right to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Miller & Lux, Inc. v. Nickel
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under California law, proof that an individual owns all of the stock of a corporation and that corporation is in truth and fact but corporate double of the owner of the stock will, in conjunction with a further showing that as a result of the double relationship fraud or injustice will inure to a third person, suffice to dissipate the separate identity of the corporation.
Document Preview: Action by corporation against several of its former officers and directors to recover property allegedly obtained by fraud. Defendants moved to dismiss. The District Court, Oliver J. Carter, J., held, inter alia, that where bona fide corporation had existed for many years, that all stock came to be owned by a trustee did not warrant disregarding to corporate entity, and thus trustees and trust beneficiaries were not indispensable parties to an action by the corporation. Order in accordance with opinion.
